AHRS_COMP_BETA.Description: This controls the time constant for the cross-over frequency used to fuse AHRS (airspeed and heading) and GPS data to estimate ground velocity. Time constant is 0.1/beta. A larger time constant will use GPS data less and a small time constant will use air data less.
AHRS_COMP_BETA.DisplayName: AHRS Velocity Complementary Filter Beta Coefficient

AHRS_CUSTOM_PIT.Description: Autopilot mounting position pitch offset. Positive values = pitch up, negative values = pitch down. This parameter is only used when AHRS_ORIENTATION is set to CUSTOM.

AHRS_CUSTOM_ROLL.Description: Autopilot mounting position roll offset. Positive values = roll right, negative values = roll left. This parameter is only used when AHRS_ORIENTATION is set to CUSTOM.

AHRS_CUSTOM_YAW.Description: Autopilot mounting position yaw offset. Positive values = yaw right, negative values = yaw left. This parameter is only used when AHRS_ORIENTATION is set to CUSTOM.

AHRS_EKF_TYPE.Description: This controls which NavEKF Kalman filter version is used for attitude and position estimation
AHRS_EKF_TYPE.DisplayName: Use NavEKF Kalman filter for attitude and position estimation

AHRS_GPS_GAIN.Description: This controls how much to use the GPS to correct the attitude. This should never be set to zero for a plane as it would result in the plane losing control in turns. For a plane please use the default value of 1.0.

AHRS_GPS_MINSATS.Description: Minimum number of satellites visible to use GPS for velocity based corrections attitude correction. This defaults to 6, which is about the point at which the velocity numbers from a GPS become too unreliable for accurate correction of the accelerometers.

AHRS_GPS_USE.Description: This controls whether to use dead-reckoning or GPS based navigation. If set to 0 then the GPS won't be used for navigation, and only dead reckoning will be used. A value of zero should never be used for normal flight. Currently this affects only the DCM-based AHRS: the EKF uses GPS according to its own parameters. A value of 2 means to use GPS for height as well as position - both in DCM estimation and when determining altitude-above-home.
AHRS_GPS_USE.DisplayName: AHRS use GPS for DCM navigation and position-down

Values.2: Use GPS for DCM position and height

AHRS_OPTIONS.Description: This controls optional AHRS behaviour. Setting DisableDCMFallbackFW will change the AHRS behaviour for fixed wing aircraft in fly-forward flight to not fall back to DCM when the EKF stops navigating. Setting DisableDCMFallbackVTOL will change the AHRS behaviour for fixed wing aircraft in non fly-forward (VTOL) flight to not fall back to DCM when the EKF stops navigating. Setting DontDisableAirspeedUsingEKF disables the EKF based innovation check for airspeed consistency

AHRS_ORIENTATION.Description: Overall board orientation relative to the standard orientation for the board type. This rotates the IMU and compass readings to allow the board to be oriented in your vehicle at any 90 or 45 degree angle. The label for each option is specified in the order of rotations for that orientation. This option takes affect on next boot. After changing you will need to re-level your vehicle. Firmware versions 4.2 and prior can use a CUSTOM (100) rotation to set the AHRS_CUSTOM_ROLL/PIT/YAW angles for AHRS orientation. Later versions provide two general custom rotations which can be used, Custom 1 and Custom 2, with CUST_ROT1_ROLL/PIT/YAW or CUST_ROT2_ROLL/PIT/YAW angles.

AHRS_RP_P.Description: This controls how fast the accelerometers correct the attitude

AHRS_TRIM_X.Description: Compensates for the roll angle difference between the control board and the frame. Positive values make the vehicle roll right.

AHRS_TRIM_Y.Description: Compensates for the pitch angle difference between the control board and the frame. Positive values make the vehicle pitch up/back.

AHRS_WIND_MAX.Description: This sets the maximum allowable difference between ground speed and airspeed. A value of zero means to use the airspeed as is. This allows the plane to cope with a failing airspeed sensor by clipping it to groundspeed plus/minus this limit. See ARSPD_OPTIONS and ARSPD_WIND_MAX to disable airspeed sensors.

AHRS_YAW_P.Description: This controls the weight the compass or GPS has on the heading. A higher value means the heading will track the yaw source (GPS or compass) more rapidly.

ADSB_PORT.Description: This is the serial port number where SERIALx_PROTOCOL will be set to ADSB.

BATT_HIDE_MASK.Description: Instance mask of local battery index(es) to prevent transmitting their status over CAN. This is useful for hiding a "battery" instance that is used locally in the peripheral but don't want them to be treated as a battery source(s) to the autopilot. For example, an AP_Periph battery monitor with multiple batteries that monitors each locally for diagnostic or other purposes, but only reports as a single SUM battery monitor to the autopilot.

BRD_SERIAL_NUM.Description: Non-zero positive values will be shown on the CAN App Name string

BUZZER_VOLUME.Description: Control the volume of the buzzer

CAN2_BAUDRATE.Description: Bit rate can be set up to from 10000 to 1000000

CAN2_FDBAUDRATE.Description: This sets the bitrate for the data section of CAN2.
CAN2_FDBAUDRATE.DisplayName: Set up bitrate for data section on CAN2

CAN2_PROTOCOL.Description: Enabling this option starts selected protocol that will use this virtual driver. At least one CAN port must be UAVCAN or else CAN1 gets set to UAVCAN
CAN2_PROTOCOL.DisplayName: Enable use of specific protocol to be used on this port

CAN2_TERMINATE.Description: Enable CAN software termination in this node
CAN2_TERMINATE.DisplayName: Enable CAN software termination in this node

CAN3_BAUDRATE.Description: Bit rate can be set up to from 10000 to 1000000

CAN3_PROTOCOL.Description: Enabling this option starts selected protocol that will use this virtual driver. At least one CAN port must be UAVCAN or else CAN1 gets set to UAVCAN
CAN3_PROTOCOL.DisplayName: Enable use of specific protocol to be used on this port

CAN3_TERMINATE.Description: Enable CAN software termination in this node
CAN3_TERMINATE.DisplayName: Enable CAN software termination in this node

CAN_BAUDRATE.Description: Bit rate can be set up to from 10000 to 1000000

CAN_FDBAUDRATE.Description: This sets the bitrate for the data section of CAN1.
CAN_FDBAUDRATE.DisplayName: Set up bitrate for data section on CAN1

CAN_FDMODE.Description: Enabling this option sets the CAN bus to be in CANFD mode with BRS.

CAN_MIRROR_PORTS.Description: Any set ports will participate in blindly mirroring traffic from one port to the other. It is the users responsibility to ensure that no loops exist that cause traffic to be infinitly repeated, and both ports must be running the same baud rates.
CAN_MIRROR_PORTS.DisplayName: CAN ports to mirror traffic between

CAN_NODE.Description: Value of 0 requests any ID from a DNA server, any other value sets that ID ignoring DNA
CAN_NODE.DisplayName: DroneCAN node ID used by this node on all networks

CAN_PROTOCOL.Description: Enabling this option starts selected protocol that will use this virtual driver. At least one CAN port must be UAVCAN or else CAN1 gets set to UAVCAN
CAN_PROTOCOL.DisplayName: Enable use of specific protocol to be used on this port

CAN_SLCAN_CPORT.Description: CAN Interface ID to be routed to SLCAN, 0 means no routing

CAN_TERMINATE.Description: Enable CAN software termination in this node
CAN_TERMINATE.DisplayName: Enable CAN software termination in this node

EFI_PORT.Description: This is the serial port number where SERIALx_PROTOCOL will be set to EFI.

ESC_APD_SERIAL_1.Description: Which serial port to use for APD ESC data

ESC_APD_SERIAL_2.Description: Which serial port to use for APD ESC data

ESC_CMD_TIMO.Description: This is the duration (ms) with which to hold the last driven ESC command before timing out and zeroing the ESC outputs. To disable zeroing of outputs in event of CAN loss, use 0. Use values greater than the expected duration between two CAN frames to ensure Periph is not starved of ESC Raw Commands.

ESC_EXT_TLM_RATE.Description: This is the rate at which extended ESC Telemetry will be sent across the CAN bus for each ESC

ESC_NUMBER.Description: This is the ESC number to report as in UAVCAN ESC telemetry feedback packets.

ESC_PWM_TYPE.Description: This selects the output PWM type, allowing for normal PWM continuous output, OneShot, brushed or DShot motor output

ESC_RATE.Description: Rate in Hz that ESC PWM outputs (function is MotorN) will update at

ESC_TELEM_PORT.Description: This is the serial port number where SERIALx_PROTOCOL will be set to ESC Telemetry

ESC_TELEM_RATE.Description: This is the rate at which ESC Telemetry will be sent across the CAN bus

FLASH_BOOTLOADER.Description: DANGER! When enabled, the App will perform a bootloader update by copying the embedded bootloader over the existing bootloader. This may take a few seconds to perform and should only be done if you know what you're doing.

FORMAT_VERSION.Description: This value is incremented when changes are made to the eeprom format

GPS_PORT.Description: This is the serial port number where SERIALx_PROTOCOL will be set to GPS.

LED_BRIGHTNESS.Description: Select the RGB LED brightness level.

LOG_BITMASK.Description: 4 byte bitmap of log types to enable

MB_CAN_PORT.Description: Autoselect dedicated CAN port on which moving baseline data will be transmitted.

Values.0: Sends moving baseline data on all ports
Values.1: auto select remaining port for transmitting Moving baseline Data

MSP_PORT.Description: This is the serial port number where SERIALx_PROTOCOL will be set to MSP

PRX_MAX_RATE.Description: This is the maximum rate we send Proximity Sensor data in Hz. Zero means no limit

PRX_PORT.Description: This is the serial port number where SERIALx_PROTOCOL will be set to Proximity Sensor.

RNGFND2_PORT.Description: This is the serial port number where SERIALx_PROTOCOL will be set to Rangefinder.

RNGFND_MAX_RATE.Description: This is the maximum rate we send rangefinder data in Hz. Zero means no limit

RNGFND_PORT.Description: This is the serial port number where SERIALx_PROTOCOL will be set to Rangefinder.

RPM_MSG_RATE.Description: This is the rate RPM sensor data is sent in Hz. Zero means no send. Each sensor with a set ID is sent in turn.

TEMP_MSG_RATE.Description: This is the rate Temperature sensor data is sent in Hz. Zero means no send. Each sensor with source DroneCAN is sent in turn.

ARSPD_OFF_PCNT.Description: The maximum percentage speed change in airspeed reports that is allowed due to offset changes between calibrations before a warning is issued. This potential speed error is in percent of AIRSPEED_MIN. 0 disables. Helps warn of calibrations without pitot being covered.

ARSPD_OPTIONS.Description: Bitmask of options to use with airspeed. 0:Disable use based on airspeed/groundspeed mismatch (see ARSPD_WIND_MAX), 1:Automatically reenable use based on airspeed/groundspeed mismatch recovery (see ARSPD_WIND_MAX) 2:Disable voltage correction, 3:Check that the airspeed is statistically consistent with the navigation EKF vehicle and wind velocity estimates using EKF3 (requires AHRS_EKF_TYPE = 3), 4:Report cal offset to GCS

ARSPD_PRIMARY.Description: This selects which airspeed sensor will be the primary if multiple sensors are found

ARSPD_TUBE_ORDER.Description: This parameter allows you to control whether the order in which the tubes are attached to your pitot tube matters. If you set this to 0 then the first (often the top) connector on the sensor needs to be the stagnation pressure (the pressure at the tip of the pitot tube). If set to 1 then the second (often the bottom) connector needs to be the stagnation pressure. If set to 2 (the default) then the airspeed driver will accept either order. The reason you may wish to specify the order is it will allow your airspeed sensor to detect if the aircraft is receiving excessive pressure on the static port compared to the stagnation port such as during a stall, which would otherwise be seen as a positive airspeed.

ARSPD_WIND_GATE.Description: Number of standard deviations applied to the re-enable EKF consistency check that is used when ARSPD_OPTIONS bit position 3 is set. Larger values will make the re-enabling of the airspeed sensor faster, but increase the likelihood of re-enabling a degraded sensor. The value can be tuned by using the ARSP.TR log message by setting ARSPD_WIND_GATE to a value that is higher than the value for ARSP.TR observed with a healthy airspeed sensor. Occasional transients in ARSP.TR above the value set by ARSPD_WIND_GATE can be tolerated provided they are less than 5 seconds in duration and less than 10% duty cycle.

ARSPD_WIND_MAX.Description: If the difference between airspeed and ground speed is greater than this value the sensor will be marked unhealthy. Using ARSPD_OPTIONS this health value can be used to disable the sensor.
ARSPD_WIND_MAX.DisplayName: Maximum airspeed and ground speed difference

ARSPD_WIND_WARN.Description: If the difference between airspeed and GPS speed is greater than this value the sensor will issue a warning. If 0 ARSPD_WIND_MAX is used.
ARSPD_WIND_WARN.DisplayName: Airspeed and GPS speed difference that gives a warning

ARSPD2_AUTOCAL.Description: Enables automatic adjustment of airspeed ratio during a calibration flight based on estimation of ground speed and true airspeed. New ratio saved every 2 minutes if change is > 5%. Should not be left enabled.

ARSPD2_BUS.Description: Bus number of the I2C bus where the airspeed sensor is connected. May not correspond to board's I2C bus number labels. Retry another bus and reboot if airspeed sensor fails to initialize.

ARSPD2_DEVID.Description: Airspeed sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

ARSPD2_PIN.Description: The pin number that the airspeed sensor is connected to for analog sensors. Values for some autopilots are given as examples. Search wiki for "Analog pins".

ARSPD2_PSI_RANGE.Description: This parameter allows you to set the PSI (pounds per square inch) range for your sensor. You should not change this unless you examine the datasheet for your device
ARSPD2_PSI_RANGE.DisplayName: The PSI range of the device

ARSPD2_RATIO.Description: Calibrates pitot tube pressure to velocity. Increasing this value will indicate a higher airspeed at any given dynamic pressure.

ARSPD2_SKIP_CAL.Description: This parameter allows you to skip airspeed offset calibration on startup, instead using the offset from the last calibration or requiring a manual calibration. This may be desirable if the offset variance between flights for your sensor is low and you want to avoid having to cover the pitot tube on each boot.
ARSPD2_SKIP_CAL.DisplayName: Skip airspeed offset calibration on startup

Values.1: Do not require offset calibration before flight. Manual calibration should be performed during initial setup.
Values.2: Do not calibrate on start up. Manual calibration must be performed once per boot.

ARSPD2_TUBE_ORDR.Description: This parameter allows you to control whether the order in which the tubes are attached to your pitot tube matters. If you set this to 0 then the first (often the top) connector on the sensor needs to be the stagnation pressure (the pressure at the tip of the pitot tube). If set to 1 then the second (often the bottom) connector needs to be the stagnation pressure. If set to 2 (the default) then the airspeed driver will accept either order. The reason you may wish to specify the order is it will allow your airspeed sensor to detect if the aircraft is receiving excessive pressure on the static port compared to the stagnation port such as during a stall, which would otherwise be seen as a positive airspeed.

ARSPD2_USE.Description: Enables airspeed use for automatic throttle modes and replaces control from THR_TRIM. Continues to display and log airspeed if set to 0. Uses airspeed for control if set to 1. Only uses airspeed when throttle = 0 if set to 2 (useful for gliders with airspeed sensors behind propellers).

ARSPD_AUTOCAL.Description: Enables automatic adjustment of airspeed ratio during a calibration flight based on estimation of ground speed and true airspeed. New ratio saved every 2 minutes if change is > 5%. Should not be left enabled.

ARSPD_BUS.Description: Bus number of the I2C bus where the airspeed sensor is connected. May not correspond to board's I2C bus number labels. Retry another bus and reboot if airspeed sensor fails to initialize.

ARSPD_DEVID.Description: Airspeed sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

ARSPD_PIN.Description: The pin number that the airspeed sensor is connected to for analog sensors. Values for some autopilots are given as examples. Search wiki for "Analog pins".

ARSPD_PSI_RANGE.Description: This parameter allows you to set the PSI (pounds per square inch) range for your sensor. You should not change this unless you examine the datasheet for your device
ARSPD_PSI_RANGE.DisplayName: The PSI range of the device

ARSPD_RATIO.Description: Calibrates pitot tube pressure to velocity. Increasing this value will indicate a higher airspeed at any given dynamic pressure.

ARSPD_SKIP_CAL.Description: This parameter allows you to skip airspeed offset calibration on startup, instead using the offset from the last calibration or requiring a manual calibration. This may be desirable if the offset variance between flights for your sensor is low and you want to avoid having to cover the pitot tube on each boot.
ARSPD_SKIP_CAL.DisplayName: Skip airspeed offset calibration on startup

Values.1: Do not require offset calibration before flight. Manual calibration should be performed during initial setup.
Values.2: Do not calibrate on start up. Manual calibration must be performed once per boot.

ARSPD_TUBE_ORDR.Description: This parameter allows you to control whether the order in which the tubes are attached to your pitot tube matters. If you set this to 0 then the first (often the top) connector on the sensor needs to be the stagnation pressure (the pressure at the tip of the pitot tube). If set to 1 then the second (often the bottom) connector needs to be the stagnation pressure. If set to 2 (the default) then the airspeed driver will accept either order. The reason you may wish to specify the order is it will allow your airspeed sensor to detect if the aircraft is receiving excessive pressure on the static port compared to the stagnation port such as during a stall, which would otherwise be seen as a positive airspeed.

ARSPD_USE.Description: Enables airspeed use for automatic throttle modes and replaces control from THR_TRIM. Continues to display and log airspeed if set to 0. Uses airspeed for control if set to 1. Only uses airspeed when throttle = 0 if set to 2 (useful for gliders with airspeed sensors behind propellers).

BAL_CELL1_PIN.Description: Analog pin of the first cell. Later cells must be sequential

BAL_ID.Description: Battery ID to match against other batteries

BAL_NUM_CELLS.Description: Number of battery cells to monitor

BARO1_DEVID.Description: Barometer sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

BARO1_THST_SCALE.Description: Thrust scaling in Pascals. This value scaled by the normalized thrust is subtracted from the barometer pressure. This is used to adjust linearly based on the thrust output for local pressure difference induced by the props.

BARO2_DEVID.Description: Barometer2 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

BARO3_DEVID.Description: Barometer3 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

BARO_ALTERR_MAX.Description: This is the maximum acceptable altitude discrepancy between GPS altitude and barometric presssure altitude calculated against a standard atmosphere for arming checks to pass. If you are getting an arming error due to this parameter then you may have a faulty or substituted barometer. A common issue is vendors replacing a MS5611 in a "Pixhawk" with a MS5607. If you have that issue then please see BARO_OPTIONS parameter to force the MS5611 to be treated as a MS5607. This check is disabled if the value is zero.

BARO_ALT_OFFSET.Description: altitude offset in meters added to barometric altitude. This is used to allow for automatic adjustment of the base barometric altitude by a ground station equipped with a barometer. The value is added to the barometric altitude read by the aircraft. It is automatically reset to 0 when the barometer is calibrated on each reboot or when a preflight calibration is performed.

BARO_EXT_BUS.Description: This selects the bus number for looking for an I2C barometer. When set to -1 it will probe all external i2c buses based on the BARO_PROBE_EXT parameter.

BARO_FIELD_ELV.Description: User provided field elevation in meters. This is used to improve the calculation of the altitude the vehicle is at. This parameter is not persistent and will be reset to 0 every time the vehicle is rebooted. Changes to this parameter will only be used when disarmed. A value of 0 means the EKF origin height is used for takeoff height above sea level.

BARO_FLTR_RNG.Description: This sets the range around the average value that new samples must be within to be accepted. This can help reduce the impact of noise on sensors that are on long I2C cables. The value is a percentage from the average value. A value of zero disables this filter.
BARO_FLTR_RNG.DisplayName: Range in which sample is accepted

BARO_GND_TEMP.Description: User provided ambient ground temperature in degrees Celsius. This is used to improve the calculation of the altitude the vehicle is at. This parameter is not persistent and will be reset to 0 every time the vehicle is rebooted. A value of 0 means use the internal measurement ambient temperature.

BARO_PRIMARY.Description: This selects which barometer will be the primary if multiple barometers are found

BARO_PROBE_EXT.Description: This sets which types of external i2c barometer to look for. It is a bitmask of barometer types. The I2C buses to probe is based on BARO_EXT_BUS. If BARO_EXT_BUS is -1 then it will probe all external buses, otherwise it will probe just the bus number given in BARO_EXT_BUS.

BARO1_WCF_BCK.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a negative wind relative velocity along the X body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during backwards flight, then this will be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO1_WCF_BCK.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in negative X direction (backwards)

BARO1_WCF_DN.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a negative wind relative velocity along the Z body axis. If the baro height estimate rises above truth height during descending flight (or forward flight with a high backwards lean angle, eg braking manoeuvre), then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO1_WCF_DN.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in negative Z direction (down)

BARO1_WCF_ENABLE.Description: This enables the use of wind coefficients for barometer compensation

BARO1_WCF_FWD.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a positive wind relative velocity along the X body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during forwards flight, then this will be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO1_WCF_FWD.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in positive X direction (forward)

BARO1_WCF_LFT.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a negative wind relative velocity along the Y body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during sideways flight to the left, then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO1_WCF_LFT.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in negative Y direction (left)

BARO1_WCF_RGT.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a positive wind relative velocity along the Y body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during sideways flight to the right, then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO1_WCF_RGT.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in positive Y direction (right)

BARO1_WCF_UP.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a positive wind relative velocity along the Z body axis. If the baro height estimate rises above truth height during climbing flight (or forward flight with a high forwards lean angle), then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO1_WCF_UP.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in positive Z direction (up)

BARO2_WCF_BCK.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a negative wind relative velocity along the X body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during backwards flight, then this will be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO2_WCF_BCK.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in negative X direction (backwards)

BARO2_WCF_DN.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a negative wind relative velocity along the Z body axis. If the baro height estimate rises above truth height during descending flight (or forward flight with a high backwards lean angle, eg braking manoeuvre), then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO2_WCF_DN.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in negative Z direction (down)

BARO2_WCF_ENABLE.Description: This enables the use of wind coefficients for barometer compensation

BARO2_WCF_FWD.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a positive wind relative velocity along the X body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during forwards flight, then this will be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO2_WCF_FWD.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in positive X direction (forward)

BARO2_WCF_LFT.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a negative wind relative velocity along the Y body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during sideways flight to the left, then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO2_WCF_LFT.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in negative Y direction (left)

BARO2_WCF_RGT.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a positive wind relative velocity along the Y body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during sideways flight to the right, then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO2_WCF_RGT.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in positive Y direction (right)

BARO2_WCF_UP.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a positive wind relative velocity along the Z body axis. If the baro height estimate rises above truth height during climbing flight (or forward flight with a high forwards lean angle), then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO2_WCF_UP.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in positive Z direction (up)

BARO3_WCF_BCK.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a negative wind relative velocity along the X body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during backwards flight, then this will be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO3_WCF_BCK.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in negative X direction (backwards)

BARO3_WCF_DN.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a negative wind relative velocity along the Z body axis. If the baro height estimate rises above truth height during descending flight (or forward flight with a high backwards lean angle, eg braking manoeuvre), then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO3_WCF_DN.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in negative Z direction (down)

BARO3_WCF_ENABLE.Description: This enables the use of wind coefficients for barometer compensation

BARO3_WCF_FWD.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a positive wind relative velocity along the X body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during forwards flight, then this will be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO3_WCF_FWD.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in positive X direction (forward)

BARO3_WCF_LFT.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a negative wind relative velocity along the Y body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during sideways flight to the left, then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO3_WCF_LFT.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in negative Y direction (left)

BARO3_WCF_RGT.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a positive wind relative velocity along the Y body axis. If the baro height estimate rises during sideways flight to the right, then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO3_WCF_RGT.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in positive Y direction (right)

BARO3_WCF_UP.Description: This is the ratio of static pressure error to dynamic pressure generated by a positive wind relative velocity along the Z body axis. If the baro height estimate rises above truth height during climbing flight (or forward flight with a high forwards lean angle), then this should be a negative number. Multirotors can use this feature only if using EKF3 and if the EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_X and EK3_DRAG_BCOEF_Y parameters have been tuned.
BARO3_WCF_UP.DisplayName: Pressure error coefficient in positive Z direction (up)

BATT2_AMP_OFFSET.Description: Voltage offset at zero current on current sensor

BATT2_AMP_PERVLT.Description: Number of amps that a 1V reading on the current sensor corresponds to.

BATT2_ARM_MAH.Description: Battery capacity remaining which is required to arm the aircraft. Set to 0 to allow arming at any capacity. Note that execept for smart batteries rebooting the vehicle will always reset the remaining capacity estimate, which can lead to this check not providing sufficent protection, it is recommended to always use this in conjunction with the BATT2_ARM_VOLT parameter.

BATT2_ARM_VOLT.Description: Battery voltage level which is required to arm the aircraft. Set to 0 to allow arming at any voltage.

BATT2_CAPACITY.Description: Capacity of the battery in mAh when full

BATT2_CHANNEL.Description: INA3221 channel to return data for

BATT2_CRT_MAH.Description: Battery capacity at which the critical battery failsafe is triggered. Set to 0 to disable battery remaining failsafe. If the battery capacity drops below this level the vehicle will perform the failsafe specified by the BATT2_FS_CRT_ACT parameter.

BATT2_CRT_VOLT.Description: Battery voltage that triggers a critical battery failsafe. Set to 0 to disable. If the battery voltage drops below this voltage continuously for more then the period specified by the BATT2_LOW_TIMER parameter then the vehicle will perform the failsafe specified by the BATT2_FS_CRT_ACT parameter.

BATT2_CURR_MULT.Description: Multiplier applied to all current related reports to allow for adjustment if no UAVCAN param access or current splitting applications

BATT2_CURR_PIN.Description: Sets the analog input pin that should be used for Current monitoring on AD7091R5.

BATT2_ESC_INDEX.Description: ESC Telemetry Index to write voltage, current, consumption and temperature data to. Use 0 to disable.
BATT2_ESC_INDEX.DisplayName: ESC Telemetry Index to write to

BATT2_ESC_MASK.Description: If 0 all connected ESCs will be used. If non-zero, only those selected in will be used.

BATT2_FL_FLTR.Description: Filter frequency in Hertz where a low pass filter is used. This is used to filter out tank slosh from the fuel level reading. A value of -1 disables the filter and unfiltered voltage is used to determine the fuel level. The suggested values at in the range of 0.2 Hz to 0.5 Hz.

BATT2_FL_PIN.Description: Analog input pin that fuel level sensor is connected to.Analog Airspeed or RSSI ports can be used for Analog input( some autopilots provide others also). Values for some autopilots are given as examples. Search wiki for "Analog pins".

BATT2_FL_VLT_MIN.Description: The voltage seen on the analog pin when the fuel tank is empty. Note: For this type of battery monitor, the voltage seen by the analog pin is displayed as battery voltage on a GCS.

BATT2_FL_V_MULT.Description: Voltage multiplier to determine what the full tank voltage reading is. This is calculated as 1 / (Voltage_Full - Voltage_Empty) Note: For this type of battery monitor, the voltage seen by the analog pin is displayed as battery voltage on a GCS.

BATT2_FS_VOLTSRC.Description: Voltage type used for detection of low voltage event

BATT2_I2C_ADDR.Description: Battery monitor I2C address. If this is zero then probe list of supported addresses

BATT2_LOW_MAH.Description: Battery capacity at which the low battery failsafe is triggered. Set to 0 to disable battery remaining failsafe. If the battery capacity drops below this level the vehicle will perform the failsafe specified by the BATT2_FS_LOW_ACT parameter.

BATT2_LOW_TIMER.Description: This is the timeout in seconds before a low voltage event will be triggered. For aircraft with low C batteries it may be necessary to raise this in order to cope with low voltage on long takeoffs. A value of zero disables low voltage errors.

BATT2_LOW_VOLT.Description: Battery voltage that triggers a low battery failsafe. Set to 0 to disable. If the battery voltage drops below this voltage continuously for more then the period specified by the BATT2_LOW_TIMER parameter then the vehicle will perform the failsafe specified by the BATT2_FS_LOW_ACT parameter.

BATT2_MAX_AMPS.Description: This controls the maximum current the INA239 sensor will work with.

BATT2_MAX_VOLT.Description: Maximum voltage of battery. Provides scaling of current versus voltage

BATT2_MONITOR.Description: Controls enabling monitoring of the battery's voltage and current

Bitmask.1: MPPT reports input voltage and current
Bitmask.6: Send resistance compensated voltage to GCS
Bitmask.7: Allow DroneCAN InfoAux to be from a different CAN node
Bitmask.8: Battery is for internal autopilot use only
Bitmask.9: Sum monitor measures minimum voltage instead of average

BATT2_OPTIONS.Description: This sets options to change the behaviour of the battery monitor

BATT2_SERIAL_NUM.Description: Battery serial number, automatically filled in for SMBus batteries, otherwise will be -1. With DroneCan it is the battery_id.

BATT2_SHUNT.Description: This sets the shunt resistor used in the device

BATT2_SUM_MASK.Description: 0: sum of remaining battery monitors, If none 0 sum of specified monitors. Current will be summed and voltages averaged.

BATT2_VLT_OFFSET.Description: Voltage offset on voltage pin. This allows for an offset due to a diode. This voltage is subtracted before the scaling is applied

BATT2_VOLT_MULT.Description: Used to convert the voltage of the voltage sensing pin (BATT2_VOLT_PIN) to the actual battery's voltage (pin_voltage * VOLT_MULT).

BATT2_VOLT_PIN.Description: Sets the analog input pin that should be used for voltage monitoring on AD7091R5.
BATT2_VOLT_PIN.DisplayName: Battery Voltage sensing pin on the AD7091R5 Ic

A value of -1 disables the filter and unfiltered voltage is used to determine the fuel level. The suggested values at in the range of 0.2 Hz to 0.5 Hz.

BATT7_FL_PIN.Description: Analog input pin that fuel level sensor is connected to.Analog Airspeed or RSSI ports can be used for Analog input( some autopilots provide others also). Values for some autopilots are given as examples. Search wiki for "Analog pins".

BATT7_FL_VLT_MIN.Description: The voltage seen on the analog pin when the fuel tank is empty. Note: For this type of battery monitor, the voltage seen by the analog pin is displayed as battery voltage on a GCS.

BATT7_FL_V_MULT.Description: Voltage multiplier to determine what the full tank voltage reading is. This is calculated as 1 / (Voltage_Full - Voltage_Empty) Note: For this type of battery monitor, the voltage seen by the analog pin is displayed as battery voltage on a GCS.

BATT7_FS_VOLTSRC.Description: Voltage type used for detection of low voltage event

BATT7_I2C_ADDR.Description: Battery monitor I2C address. If this is zero then probe list of supported addresses

BATT7_LOW_MAH.Description: Battery capacity at which the low battery failsafe is triggered. Set to 0 to disable battery remaining failsafe. If the battery capacity drops below this level the vehicle will perform the failsafe specified by the BATT7_FS_LOW_ACT parameter.

BATT7_LOW_TIMER.Description: This is the timeout in seconds before a low voltage event will be triggered. For aircraft with low C batteries it may be necessary to raise this in order to cope with low voltage on long takeoffs. A value of zero disables low voltage errors.

BATT7_LOW_VOLT.Description: Battery voltage that triggers a low battery failsafe. Set to 0 to disable. If the battery voltage drops below this voltage continuously for more then the period specified by the BATT7_LOW_TIMER parameter then the vehicle will perform the failsafe specified by the BATT7_FS_LOW_ACT parameter.

BATT7_MAX_AMPS.Description: This controls the maximum current the INA239 sensor will work with.

BATT7_MAX_VOLT.Description: Maximum voltage of battery. Provides scaling of current versus voltage

BATT7_MONITOR.Description: Controls enabling monitoring of the battery's voltage and current

Bitmask.1: MPPT reports input voltage and current
Bitmask.6: Send resistance compensated voltage to GCS
Bitmask.7: Allow DroneCAN InfoAux to be from a different CAN node
Bitmask.8: Battery is for internal autopilot use only
Bitmask.9: Sum monitor measures minimum voltage instead of average

BATT7_OPTIONS.Description: This sets options to change the behaviour of the battery monitor

BATT7_SERIAL_NUM.Description: Battery serial number, automatically filled in for SMBus batteries, otherwise will be -1. With DroneCan it is the battery_id.

BATT7_SHUNT.Description: This sets the shunt resistor used in the device

BATT7_SUM_MASK.Description: 0: sum of remaining battery monitors, If none 0 sum of specified monitors. Current will be summed and voltages averaged.

BATT7_VLT_OFFSET.Description: Voltage offset on voltage pin. This allows for an offset due to a diode. This voltage is subtracted before the scaling is applied

BATT7_VOLT_MULT.Description: Used to convert the voltage of the voltage sensing pin (BATT7_VOLT_PIN) to the actual battery's voltage (pin_voltage * VOLT_MULT).

BATT7_VOLT_PIN.Description: Sets the analog input pin that should be used for voltage monitoring on AD7091R5.
BATT7_VOLT_PIN.DisplayName: Battery Voltage sensing pin on the AD7091R5 Ic

BATT8_AMP_OFFSET.Description: Voltage offset at zero current on current sensor

BATT8_AMP_PERVLT.Description: Number of amps that a 1V reading on the current sensor corresponds to.

BATT8_ARM_MAH.Description: Battery capacity remaining which is required to arm the aircraft. Set to 0 to allow arming at any capacity. Note that execept for smart batteries rebooting the vehicle will always reset the remaining capacity estimate, which can lead to this check not providing sufficent protection, it is recommended to always use this in conjunction with the BATT8_ARM_VOLT parameter.

BATTC_VOLT_MULT.Description: Used to convert the voltage of the voltage sensing pin (BATTC_VOLT_PIN) to the actual battery's voltage (pin_voltage * VOLT_MULT).

BATTC_VOLT_PIN.Description: Sets the analog input pin that should be used for voltage monitoring on AD7091R5.

BTAG_ARM_HOURS.Description: Number of hours the battery has been armed

BTAG_CYCLE_MIN.Description: Cycle minimum time. Minimum time that vehicle is armed in minutes for counting a battery cycle

BTAG_FIRST_USE.Description: First use time in minutes since 1/1/1970

BTAG_LAST_USE.Description: Last use time in minutes since 1/1/1970

BTAG_NUM_CYCLES.Description: Number of cycles the battery has been through

COMPASS_AUTODEC.Description: Enable or disable the automatic calculation of the declination based on gps location

COMPASS_AUTO_ROT.Description: When enabled this will automatically check the orientation of compasses on successful completion of compass calibration. If set to 2 then external compasses will have their orientation automatically corrected.

Values.3: use same tolerance to auto rotate 45 deg rotations

COMPASS_CAL_FIT.Description: This controls the fitness level required for a successful compass calibration. A lower value makes for a stricter fit (less likely to pass). This is the value used for the primary magnetometer. Other magnetometers get double the value.

COMPASS_CUS_PIT.Description: Compass mounting position pitch offset. Positive values = pitch up, negative values = pitch down. This parameter is only used when COMPASS_ORIENT/2/3 is set to CUSTOM.

COMPASS_CUS_ROLL.Description: Compass mounting position roll offset. Positive values = roll right, negative values = roll left. This parameter is only used when COMPASS_ORIENT/2/3 is set to CUSTOM.

COMPASS_CUS_YAW.Description: Compass mounting position yaw offset. Positive values = yaw right, negative values = yaw left. This parameter is only used when COMPASS_ORIENT/2/3 is set to CUSTOM.

COMPASS_DEC.Description: An angle to compensate between the true north and magnetic north

COMPASS_DEV_ID.Description: Compass device id.  Automatically detected, do not set manually

COMPASS_DEV_ID2.Description: Second compass's device id.  Automatically detected, do not set manually

COMPASS_DEV_ID3.Description: Third compass's device id.  Automatically detected, do not set manually

COMPASS_DEV_ID4.Description: Extra 4th compass's device id.  Automatically detected, do not set manually

COMPASS_DEV_ID5.Description: Extra 5th compass's device id.  Automatically detected, do not set manually

COMPASS_DEV_ID6.Description: Extra 6th compass's device id.  Automatically detected, do not set manually

COMPASS_DEV_ID7.Description: Extra 7th compass's device id.  Automatically detected, do not set manually

COMPASS_DEV_ID8.Description: Extra 8th compass's device id.  Automatically detected, do not set manually

COMPASS_DIA2_X.Description: DIA_X in the compass2 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_DIA2_Y.Description: DIA_Y in the compass2 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_DIA2_Z.Description: DIA_Z in the compass2 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_DIA3_X.Description: DIA_X in the compass3 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_DIA3_Y.Description: DIA_Y in the compass3 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_DIA3_Z.Description: DIA_Z in the compass3 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_DIA_X.Description: DIA_X in the compass soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_DIA_Y.Description: DIA_Y in the compass soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_DIA_Z.Description: DIA_Z in the compass soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_DISBLMSK.Description: This is a bitmask of driver types to disable. If a driver type is set in this mask then that driver will not try to find a sensor at startup

COMPASS_ENABLE.Description: Setting this to Enabled(1) will enable the compass. Setting this to Disabled(0) will disable the compass. Note that this is separate from COMPASS_USE. This will enable the low level senor, and will enable logging of magnetometer data. To use the compass for navigation you must also set COMPASS_USE to 1.

COMPASS_EXTERN2.Description: Configure second compass so it is attached externally. This is auto-detected on most boards. If set to 0 or 1 then auto-detection by bus connection can override the value. If set to 2 then auto-detection will be disabled.
COMPASS_EXTERN2.DisplayName: Compass2 is attached via an external cable

COMPASS_EXTERN3.Description: Configure third compass so it is attached externally. This is auto-detected on most boards. If set to 0 or 1 then auto-detection by bus connection can override the value. If set to 2 then auto-detection will be disabled.
COMPASS_EXTERN3.DisplayName: Compass3 is attached via an external cable

COMPASS_EXTERNAL.Description: Configure compass so it is attached externally. This is auto-detected on most boards. Set to 1 if the compass is externally connected. When externally connected the COMPASS_ORIENT option operates independently of the AHRS_ORIENTATION board orientation option. If set to 0 or 1 then auto-detection by bus connection can override the value. If set to 2 then auto-detection will be disabled.
COMPASS_EXTERNAL.DisplayName: Compass is attached via an external cable

COMPASS_FLTR_RNG.Description: This sets the range around the average value that new samples must be within to be accepted. This can help reduce the impact of noise on sensors that are on long I2C cables. The value is a percentage from the average value. A value of zero disables this filter.
COMPASS_FLTR_RNG.DisplayName: Range in which sample is accepted

COMPASS_LEARN.Description: Enable or disable the automatic learning of compass offsets. You can enable learning either using a compass-only method that is suitable only for fixed wing aircraft or using the offsets learnt by the active EKF state estimator. If this option is enabled then the learnt offsets are saved when you disarm the vehicle. If InFlight learning is enabled then the compass with automatically start learning once a flight starts (must be armed). While InFlight learning is running you cannot use position control modes.

COMPASS_MOT2_X.Description: Multiplied by the current throttle and added to compass2's x-axis values to compensate for motor interference (Offset per Amp or at Full Throttle)
COMPASS_MOT2_X.DisplayName: Motor interference compensation to compass2 for body frame X axis

COMPASS_MOT2_Y.Description: Multiplied by the current throttle and added to compass2's y-axis values to compensate for motor interference (Offset per Amp or at Full Throttle)
COMPASS_MOT2_Y.DisplayName: Motor interference compensation to compass2 for body frame Y axis

COMPASS_MOT2_Z.Description: Multiplied by the current throttle and added to compass2's z-axis values to compensate for motor interference (Offset per Amp or at Full Throttle)
COMPASS_MOT2_Z.DisplayName: Motor interference compensation to compass2 for body frame Z axis

COMPASS_MOT3_X.Description: Multiplied by the current throttle and added to compass3's x-axis values to compensate for motor interference (Offset per Amp or at Full Throttle)
COMPASS_MOT3_X.DisplayName: Motor interference compensation to compass3 for body frame X axis

COMPASS_MOT3_Y.Description: Multiplied by the current throttle and added to compass3's y-axis values to compensate for motor interference (Offset per Amp or at Full Throttle)
COMPASS_MOT3_Y.DisplayName: Motor interference compensation to compass3 for body frame Y axis

COMPASS_MOT3_Z.Description: Multiplied by the current throttle and added to compass3's z-axis values to compensate for motor interference (Offset per Amp or at Full Throttle)
COMPASS_MOT3_Z.DisplayName: Motor interference compensation to compass3 for body frame Z axis

COMPASS_MOTCT.Description: Set motor interference compensation type to disabled, throttle or current.  Do not change manually.

COMPASS_MOT_X.Description: Multiplied by the current throttle and added to the compass's x-axis values to compensate for motor interference (Offset per Amp or at Full Throttle)
COMPASS_MOT_X.DisplayName: Motor interference compensation for body frame X axis

COMPASS_MOT_Y.Description: Multiplied by the current throttle and added to the compass's y-axis values to compensate for motor interference (Offset per Amp or at Full Throttle)
COMPASS_MOT_Y.DisplayName: Motor interference compensation for body frame Y axis

COMPASS_MOT_Z.Description: Multiplied by the current throttle and added to the compass's z-axis values to compensate for motor interference (Offset per Amp or at Full Throttle)
COMPASS_MOT_Z.DisplayName: Motor interference compensation for body frame Z axis

COMPASS_ODI2_X.Description: ODI_X in the compass2 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_ODI2_Y.Description: ODI_Y in the compass2 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_ODI2_Z.Description: ODI_Z in the compass2 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_ODI3_X.Description: ODI_X in the compass3 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_ODI3_Y.Description: ODI_Y in the compass3 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_ODI3_Z.Description: ODI_Z in the compass3 soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_ODI_X.Description: ODI_X in the compass soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_ODI_Y.Description: ODI_Y in the compass soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_ODI_Z.Description: ODI_Z in the compass soft-iron calibration matrix: [[DIA_X, ODI_X, ODI_Y], [ODI_X, DIA_Y, ODI_Z], [ODI_Y, ODI_Z, DIA_Z]]

COMPASS_OFFS_MAX.Description: This sets the maximum allowed compass offset in calibration and arming checks

COMPASS_OFS2_X.Description: Offset to be added to compass2's x-axis values to compensate for metal in the frame
COMPASS_OFS2_X.DisplayName: Compass2 offsets in milligauss on the X axis

COMPASS_OFS2_Y.Description: Offset to be added to compass2's y-axis values to compensate for metal in the frame
COMPASS_OFS2_Y.DisplayName: Compass2 offsets in milligauss on the Y axis

COMPASS_OFS2_Z.Description: Offset to be added to compass2's z-axis values to compensate for metal in the frame
COMPASS_OFS2_Z.DisplayName: Compass2 offsets in milligauss on the Z axis

COMPASS_OFS3_X.Description: Offset to be added to compass3's x-axis values to compensate for metal in the frame
COMPASS_OFS3_X.DisplayName: Compass3 offsets in milligauss on the X axis

COMPASS_OFS3_Y.Description: Offset to be added to compass3's y-axis values to compensate for metal in the frame
COMPASS_OFS3_Y.DisplayName: Compass3 offsets in milligauss on the Y axis

COMPASS_OFS3_Z.Description: Offset to be added to compass3's z-axis values to compensate for metal in the frame
COMPASS_OFS3_Z.DisplayName: Compass3 offsets in milligauss on the Z axis

COMPASS_OFS_X.Description: Offset to be added to the compass x-axis values to compensate for metal in the frame
COMPASS_OFS_X.DisplayName: Compass offsets in milligauss on the X axis

COMPASS_OFS_Y.Description: Offset to be added to the compass y-axis values to compensate for metal in the frame
COMPASS_OFS_Y.DisplayName: Compass offsets in milligauss on the Y axis

COMPASS_OFS_Z.Description: Offset to be added to the compass z-axis values to compensate for metal in the frame
COMPASS_OFS_Z.DisplayName: Compass offsets in milligauss on the Z axis

Bitmask.1: Allow missing DroneCAN compasses to be automaticaly replaced (calibration still required)

COMPASS_OPTIONS.Description: This sets options to change the behaviour of the compass

COMPASS_ORIENT.Description: The orientation of the first external compass relative to the vehicle frame. This value will be ignored unless this compass is set as an external compass. When set correctly in the northern hemisphere, pointing the nose and right side down should increase the MagX and MagY values respectively. Rolling the vehicle upside down should decrease the MagZ value. For southern hemisphere, switch increase and decrease. NOTE: For internal compasses, AHRS_ORIENT is used. The label for each option is specified in the order of rotations for that orientation. Firmware versions 4.2 and prior can use a CUSTOM (100) rotation to set the COMPASS_CUS_ROLL/PIT/YAW angles for Compass orientation. Later versions provide two general custom rotations which can be used, Custom 1 and Custom 2, with CUST_1_ROLL/PIT/YAW or CUST_2_ROLL/PIT/YAW angles.

COMPASS_ORIENT2.Description: The orientation of a second external compass relative to the vehicle frame. This value will be ignored unless this compass is set as an external compass. When set correctly in the northern hemisphere, pointing the nose and right side down should increase the MagX and MagY values respectively. Rolling the vehicle upside down should decrease the MagZ value. For southern hemisphere, switch increase and decrease. NOTE: For internal compasses, AHRS_ORIENT is used. The label for each option is specified in the order of rotations for that orientation. Firmware versions 4.2 and prior can use a CUSTOM (100) rotation to set the COMPASS_CUS_ROLL/PIT/YAW angles for Compass orientation. Later versions provide two general custom rotations which can be used, Custom 1 and Custom 2, with CUST_1_ROLL/PIT/YAW or CUST_2_ROLL/PIT/YAW angles.

COMPASS_ORIENT3.Description: The orientation of a third external compass relative to the vehicle frame. This value will be ignored unless this compass is set as an external compass. When set correctly in the northern hemisphere, pointing the nose and right side down should increase the MagX and MagY values respectively. Rolling the vehicle upside down should decrease the MagZ value. For southern hemisphere, switch increase and decrease. NOTE: For internal compasses, AHRS_ORIENT is used. The label for each option is specified in the order of rotations for that orientation. Firmware versions 4.2 and prior can use a CUSTOM (100) rotation to set the COMPASS_CUS_ROLL/PIT/YAW angles for Compass orientation. Later versions provide two general custom rotations which can be used, Custom 1 and Custom 2, with CUST_1_ROLL/PIT/YAW or CUST_2_ROLL/PIT/YAW angles.

COMPASS_PRIO1_ID.Description: Compass device id with 1st order priority, set automatically if 0. Reboot required after change.
COMPASS_PRIO1_ID.DisplayName: Compass device id with 1st order priority

COMPASS_PRIO2_ID.Description: Compass device id with 2nd order priority, set automatically if 0. Reboot required after change.
COMPASS_PRIO2_ID.DisplayName: Compass device id with 2nd order priority

COMPASS_PRIO3_ID.Description: Compass device id with 3rd order priority, set automatically if 0. Reboot required after change.
COMPASS_PRIO3_ID.DisplayName: Compass device id with 3rd order priority

COMPASS_SCALE.Description: Scaling factor for first compass to compensate for sensor scaling errors. If this is 0 then no scaling is done

COMPASS_SCALE2.Description: Scaling factor for 2nd compass to compensate for sensor scaling errors. If this is 0 then no scaling is done

COMPASS_SCALE3.Description: Scaling factor for 3rd compass to compensate for sensor scaling errors. If this is 0 then no scaling is done

COMPASS_USE.Description: Enable or disable the use of the compass (instead of the GPS) for determining heading

COMPASS_USE2.Description: Enable or disable the secondary compass for determining heading.

COMPASS_USE3.Description: Enable or disable the tertiary compass for determining heading.

COMPASS_PMOT1_X.Description: Compensation for X axis of motor1

COMPASS_PMOT1_Y.Description: Compensation for Y axis of motor1

COMPASS_PMOT1_Z.Description: Compensation for Z axis of motor1

COMPASS_PMOT2_X.Description: Compensation for X axis of motor2

COMPASS_PMOT2_Y.Description: Compensation for Y axis of motor2

COMPASS_PMOT2_Z.Description: Compensation for Z axis of motor2

COMPASS_PMOT3_X.Description: Compensation for X axis of motor3

COMPASS_PMOT3_Y.Description: Compensation for Y axis of motor3

COMPASS_PMOT3_Z.Description: Compensation for Z axis of motor3

COMPASS_PMOT4_X.Description: Compensation for X axis of motor4

COMPASS_PMOT4_Y.Description: Compensation for Y axis of motor4

COMPASS_PMOT4_Z.Description: Compensation for Z axis of motor4

COMPASS_PMOT_EXP.Description: This is the exponential correction for the power output of the motor for per-motor compass correction

EFI_COEF1.Description: Used to calibrate fuel flow for MS protocol (Slope). This should be calculated from a log at constant fuel usage rate. Plot (ECYL[0].InjT*EFI.Rpm)/600.0 to get the duty_cycle. Measure actual fuel usage in cm^3/min, and set EFI_COEF1 = fuel_usage_cm3permin / duty_cycle

EFI_COEF2.Description: Used to calibrate fuel flow for MS protocol (Offset). This can be used to correct for a non-zero offset in the fuel consumption calculation of EFI_COEF1

EFI_TYPE.Description: What method of communication is used for EFI #1

EFI_THRLIN_COEF1.Description: First Order Polynomial Coefficient. (=1, if throttle is first order polynomial trendline)

EFI_THRLIN_COEF2.Description: Second Order Polynomial Coefficient (=0, if throttle is second order polynomial trendline)

EFI_THRLIN_COEF3.Description: Third Order Polynomial Coefficient. (=0, if throttle is third order polynomial trendline)

GPS_AUTO_CONFIG.Description: Controls if the autopilot should automatically configure the GPS based on the parameters and default settings

Values.1: Enable automatic configuration for Serial GPSes only
Values.2: Enable automatic configuration for DroneCAN as well

GPS_AUTO_SWITCH.Description: Automatic switchover to GPS reporting best lock, 1:UseBest selects the GPS with highest status, if both are equal the GPS with highest satellite count is used 4:Use primary if 3D fix or better, will revert to 'UseBest' behaviour if 3D fix is lost on primary

Values.4: Use primary if 3D fix or better

GPS_BLEND_MASK.Description: Determines which of the accuracy measures Horizontal position, Vertical Position and Speed are used to calculate the weighting on each GPS receiver when soft switching has been selected by setting GPS_AUTO_SWITCH to 2(Blend)

GPS_CAN_NODEID1.Description: GPS Node id for first-discovered GPS.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS1_CAN_NODEID.

GPS_CAN_NODEID2.Description: GPS Node id for second-discovered GPS.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS2_CAN_NODEID.

GPS_COM_PORT.Description: The physical COM port on the connected device, currently only applies to SBF and GSOF GPS,Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS1_COM_PORT.

GPS_COM_PORT2.Description: The physical COM port on the connected device, currently only applies to SBF and GSOF GPS.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS1_COM_PORT.

GPS_DELAY_MS.Description: Controls the amount of GPS  measurement delay that the autopilot compensates for. Set to zero to use the default delay for the detected GPS type.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS1_DELAY_MS.

GPS_DELAY_MS2.Description: Controls the amount of GPS  measurement delay that the autopilot compensates for. Set to zero to use the default delay for the detected GPS type.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS2_DELAY_MS.

Bitmask.0: Use UART2 for moving baseline on ublox
Bitmask.1: Use base station for GPS yaw on SBF
Bitmask.3: Use dedicated CAN port b/w GPSes for moving baseline
Bitmask.4: Use ellipsoid height instead of AMSL
Bitmask.5: Override GPS satellite health of L5 band from L1 health
Bitmask.6: Enable RTCM full parse even for a single channel
Bitmask.7: Disable automatic full RTCM parsing when RTCM seen on more than one channel

GPS_GNSS_MODE.Description: Bitmask for what GNSS system to use on the first GPS (all unchecked or zero to leave GPS as configured).Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS1_GNSS_MODE.

GPS_GNSS_MODE2.Description: Bitmask for what GNSS system to use on the second GPS (all unchecked or zero to leave GPS as configured). Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS2_GNSS_MODE

GPS_INJECT_TO.Description: The GGS can send raw serial packets to inject data to multiple GPSes.

GPS_MIN_ELEV.Description: This sets the minimum elevation of satellites above the horizon for them to be used for navigation. Setting this to -100 leaves the minimum elevation set to the GPS modules default.

GPS_POS1_X.Description: X position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS1_POS_X.

GPS_POS1_Y.Description: Y position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS1_POS_Y.

GPS_POS1_Z.Description: Z position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS1_POS_Z.

GPS_POS2_X.Description: X position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS2_POS_X.

GPS_POS2_Y.Description: Y position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS2_POS_Y.

GPS_POS2_Z.Description: Z position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS2_POS_Z.

GPS_PRIMARY.Description: This GPS will be used when GPS_AUTO_SWITCH is 0 and used preferentially with GPS_AUTO_SWITCH = 4.

GPS_RATE_MS.Description: Controls how often the GPS should provide a position update. Lowering below 5Hz(default) is not allowed. Raising the rate above 5Hz usually provides little benefit and for some GPS (eg Ublox M9N) can severely impact performance.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS1_RATE_MS

GPS_RATE_MS2.Description: Controls how often the GPS should provide a position update. Lowering below 5Hz(default) is not allowed. Raising the rate above 5Hz usually provides little benefit and for some GPS (eg Ublox M9N) can severely impact performance.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS2_RATE_MS

GPS_RAW_DATA.Description: Handles logging raw data; on uBlox chips that support raw data this will log RXM messages into logger; on Septentrio this will log on the equipment's SD card and when set to 2, the autopilot will try to stop logging after disarming and restart after arming

Values.5: Only log every five samples (uBlox only)

GPS_SAVE_CFG.Description: Determines whether the configuration for this GPS should be written to non-volatile memory on the GPS. Currently working for UBlox 6 series and above.

GPS_SBAS_MODE.Description: This sets the SBAS (satellite based augmentation system) mode if available on this GPS. If set to 2 then the SBAS mode is not changed in the GPS. Otherwise the GPS will be reconfigured to enable/disable SBAS. Disabling SBAS may be worthwhile in some parts of the world where an SBAS signal is available but the baseline is too long to be useful.

GPS_SBP_LOGMASK.Description: Masked with the SBP msg_type field to determine whether SBR1/SBR2 data is logged

GPS_TYPE.Description: GPS type of 1st GPS.Renamed in 4.6 and later to GPS1_TYPE

GPS1_CAN_NODEID.Description: GPS Node id for GPS.  Detected node unless CAN_OVRIDE is set
GPS1_CAN_NODEID.DisplayName: Detected CAN Node ID for GPS

GPS1_CAN_OVRIDE.Description: GPS Node id for GPS. If 0 the gps will be automatically selected on a first-come-first-GPS basis.

GPS1_COM_PORT.Description: The physical COM port on the connected device, currently only applies to SBF and GSOF GPS

GPS1_DELAY_MS.Description: Controls the amount of GPS  measurement delay that the autopilot compensates for. Set to zero to use the default delay for the detected GPS type.

GPS1_GNSS_MODE.Description: Bitmask for what GNSS system to use (all unchecked or zero to leave GPS as configured)

GPS1_POS_X.Description: X position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS1_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS1_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS1_RATE_MS.Description: Controls how often the GPS should provide a position update. Lowering below 5Hz(default) is not allowed. Raising the rate above 5Hz usually provides little benefit and for some GPS (eg Ublox M9N) can severely impact performance.

GPS1_MB_OFS_X.Description: X position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive X is forward of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_X.

GPS1_MB_OFS_Y.Description: Y position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Y is to the right of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_Y.

GPS1_MB_OFS_Z.Description: Z position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Z is down from the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_Z.

GPS1_MB_TYPE.Description: Controls the type of moving base used if using moving base.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_TYPE.

GPS2_CAN_NODEID.Description: GPS Node id for GPS.  Detected node unless CAN_OVRIDE is set
GPS2_CAN_NODEID.DisplayName: Detected CAN Node ID for GPS

GPS2_CAN_OVRIDE.Description: GPS Node id for GPS. If 0 the gps will be automatically selected on a first-come-first-GPS basis.

GPS2_COM_PORT.Description: The physical COM port on the connected device, currently only applies to SBF and GSOF GPS

GPS2_DELAY_MS.Description: Controls the amount of GPS  measurement delay that the autopilot compensates for. Set to zero to use the default delay for the detected GPS type.

GPS2_GNSS_MODE.Description: Bitmask for what GNSS system to use (all unchecked or zero to leave GPS as configured)

GPS2_POS_X.Description: X position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS2_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS2_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS2_RATE_MS.Description: Controls how often the GPS should provide a position update. Lowering below 5Hz(default) is not allowed. Raising the rate above 5Hz usually provides little benefit and for some GPS (eg Ublox M9N) can severely impact performance.

GPS2_MB_OFS_X.Description: X position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive X is forward of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_X.

GPS2_MB_OFS_Y.Description: Y position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Y is to the right of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_Y.

GPS2_MB_OFS_Z.Description: Z position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Z is down from the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_Z.

GPS2_MB_TYPE.Description: Controls the type of moving base used if using moving base.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_TYPE.

GPS_MB1_OFS_X.Description: X position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive X is forward of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_X.

GPS_MB1_OFS_Y.Description: Y position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Y is to the right of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_Y.

GPS_MB1_OFS_Z.Description: Z position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Z is down from the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_Z.

GPS_MB1_TYPE.Description: Controls the type of moving base used if using moving base.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_TYPE.

GPS_MB2_OFS_X.Description: X position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive X is forward of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_X.

GPS_MB2_OFS_Y.Description: Y position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Y is to the right of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_Y.

GPS_MB2_OFS_Z.Description: Z position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Z is down from the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_OFS_Z.

GPS_MB2_TYPE.Description: Controls the type of moving base used if using moving base.This is renamed in 4.6 and later to GPSx_MB_TYPE.

INS_GYRO_FILTER.Description: Filter cutoff frequency for gyroscopes. This can be set to a lower value to try to cope with very high vibration levels in aircraft. A value of zero means no filtering (not recommended!)

INS_GYRO_RATE.Description: Gyro rate for IMUs with fast sampling enabled. The gyro rate is the sample rate at which the IMU filters operate and needs to be at least double the maximum filter frequency. If the sensor does not support the selected rate the next highest supported rate will be used. For IMUs which do not support fast sampling this setting is ignored and the default gyro rate of 1Khz is used.
INS_GYRO_RATE.DisplayName: Gyro rate for IMUs with Fast Sampling enabled

INS_GYR_CAL.Description: Conrols when automatic gyro calibration is performed

INS_GYR_ID.Description: Gyro sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_POS1_X.Description: X position of the first IMU Accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS1_Y.Description: Y position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS1_Z.Description: Z position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_STILL_THRESH.Description: Threshold to tolerate vibration to determine if vehicle is motionless. This depends on the frame type and if there is a constant vibration due to motors before launch or after landing. Total motionless is about 0.05. Suggested values: Planes/rover use 0.1, multirotors use 1, tradHeli uses 5
INS_STILL_THRESH.DisplayName: Stillness threshold for detecting if we are moving

INS_TCAL_OPTIONS.Description: This enables optional temperature calibration features. Setting of the Persist bits will save the temperature and/or accelerometer calibration parameters in the bootloader sector on the next update of the bootloader.

INS_TRIM_OPTION.Description: Specifies how the accel cal routine determines the trims

Values.2: Assume ACC_BODYFIX is perfectly aligned to the vehicle
